document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

4D17FB52291546A9A2F412898BA962DF.description:
At the time Jesus lived, the designation
“brother and sister” also referred to cousins
and sometimes even close neighbors.

7C7C718D5D044F39A152409C3B32ED33.description:
It is not clear who the “brothers and sisters”
of Jesus are.

005DF79121B64603996795C0B895BF2D.description:
From the earliest days of the Church, Mary
has been revered as ever-virgin; she was a
virgin before Jesus’ birth and remained a
virgin afterward.

15F8BD50F6964C47B0132D4C9006BC53.description:
Questions about references in the Gospels to the
brothers and sisters of Jesus.

7DBAFD84ECF041BD92B89B5270C9AC16.description:
When Mary and the saints were on earth,
they cooperated with God to do good for
others; so now from their place in Heaven
they continue to cooperate with God by
doing good for others who are in need on
earth and in Purgatory.

3C37F4F47BDD4847B46183A4DDE72ECE.description:
When people pray to the Blessed Mother
they are asking her in turn to offer the
same prayer for them to God.

60D205DE92BB4BC5AAB2E92D3762B37B.description:
Since Mary is already in Heaven, she will
know better than we how to offer praise
and prayer to God.

18415DA8D5484A6DAE228F9F2EEED665.description:
Prayers to Mary are asking for her intercessory
help.

41A3E31F4DC24DF7B053492BD06E35E5.description:
Mary does not have the power to answer
prayers on her own; God alone has that power.

D314FD806D8746329B597D344DDF974B.description:
Catholics do not worship Mary; worship
belongs to God alone. They venerate Mary
and the saints.

839ABA2404964CA2A3C873418CB27B56.description: Questions about why Catholics pray to Mary.

A63B3D303B4F4E80A4882880304E786C.description:
How do we as Catholics answer questions about the
Blessed Virgin Mary and her role in the life and prayer
of the Church (CCC, nos. 148, 484-511, 721-726, 773,
963-972, 829)?

4E89695783854625939819AAB7FCE9BB.description:
Christ has also given the Church a share in his own
infallibility (CCC, nos. 889-892).

2A53EFDBB7A9445C949D553D1A1DAA30.description:
Jesus Christ promised his Apostles that he
would be with the Church until the end of
time (Mt 28:20).

7FC6F43BCF834D9F8DB3F9A9FB3F37A8.description:
Through the centuries, the popes and bishops,
the successors of St. Peter and the Apostles,
have carefully transmitted to the generations
whom they shepherd the truths revealed and
taught by Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 96, 171,
173, 815).

E6AA94AE2C254AAC9A8DBC1C96BCBD9E.description:
What was revealed in and through Jesus Christ
was entrusted to St. Peter and the Apostles,
who were taught directly by Jesus. They in
turn passed on those beliefs through those who
succeeded them (CCC, nos. 81, 84).

A0A593D52109495A93EF27EC193CBE60.description:
We can be sure that what the Church teaches has
come from God because of Apostolic Tradition and
Apostolic Succession (CCC, nos. 888-892, 861-
862, 858-860).

66BBE7EC6F0D4486A1AD8A6E9CDC9A07.description:
There are some who dismiss God’s Revelation and say
that the beliefs and doctrines taught by the Church
have been made up by members of the Church. How
can we be sure that what the Catholic Church teaches
has come from God?

4B8B6F8749E440D391E6603A40146C7A.description:
Jesus established his Church to help people find
true happiness and joy (CCC, no. 1832).

6E0D7243316441088CCE2F22E372A2B7.description:
True joy is the mark of followers of Christ (Phil 4:4;
CCC, no. 1832).

FD27A6CEDF73463FBB7A074A663355EA.description:
The blueprint for true discipleship and happiness
is found in Christ’s teaching of the Beatitudes (Mt
5:2-10; CCC, nos. 1716-1718).

F3AEA4E4FF734E418BCF22783D3DC842.description:
Jesus Christ taught us all he did so that we might
share in his joy (Jn 15:11), which shows us again
his desire for our happiness (CCC, nos. 736, 1832).

176E2EEFF09242F782E41878A13BF36A.description:
God sent his only Son, Jesus Christ, so that we
might be saved (Jn 3:16); that confident hope is the
cause for happiness in spite of suffering (CCC, nos.
599-605).

AB5447C27BC04585BCDBCB7EA69D740B.description:
Yes. From the beginning of Creation, God has
created us to be happy both in this world and in the
next and has shown us the ways to be truly happy.
Unhappiness was caused by people themselves
when they did not or would not listen to him
(CCC, nos. 374-379).

52EED2F5D34E422FB293812181F6D622.description: Does God really want us to be happy?

156BD55B84FD457882DD7B6FB790CF6E.description:
Natural disasters can be understood in part as a
result of Original Sin (CCC, no. 400) and also
because the world is in a state of journeying toward
ultimate perfection (CCC, no. 310); they are not
signs of God’s displeasure or punishment.

6BB2F464869A409BA8762132C463D01C.description:
We need to remember that God always wants what
is best for us (CCC, nos. 374-379).

AB85EC6555EA479ABB277E5DCFF2E6E4.description:
The Scriptures try to help us understand suffering:
the psalms, the story of Job, and the prophets
offer insights and consolation. In particular, the
Resurrection of Jesus can help us see beyond
suffering to hope and to eternal life (CCC, nos.
638-655).

45EFEB61C1D94C66A25F4AFD142C465F.description:
The Passion and Death of Jesus can help us to see
beyond suffering and remind us that God is present
with us in our suffering, pain, and death; our own
personal suffering when united to Jesus’ suffering
becomes redemptive for ourselves and others
(CCC, no. 1851).

F16C23A47CD246269F49C8E48FBC0459.description:
Some suffering is the result of human sin and is not
from God. It was God who gave us free will; sin
is the result of the misuse of this gift (CCC, nos.
1849, 1852-1853).

94FD253A8FCF48B7ACCA1BDC82C14756.description:
Evil is a reality and a mystery, that is, it is hard to
understand the why of it (CCC, nos. 309-314).
Some evil and suffering are a result of the work of
the Devil or Satan (CCC, no. 395).

4EEA0D4D77FA423AB8DCCF88DBE540B4.description:
Suffering that exists in the world is not something
caused by God or sent by God; God only brings
about what is good for he is goodness itself. When
there is evil and suffering, God does not cause it,
but sometimes he does permit it for reasons we
cannot now know or understand (CCC, nos. 1500-
1501).

2361C5FA693E4339BF2D3AAB143E4FFE.description:
How can people say that God is good if suffering and
evil are present in the world?

4593210517334394B432249028CE3170.description:
He tells us through the Church (CCC, nos.
785-786).

E181A011B6854250A34DFAC9894A5E5E.description:
He also tells us through the liturgy of the
Church, speaking to us in the Scripture
and giving himself to us in the sacraments,
especially the Eucharist (CCC, nos. 1067,
1324-1327).

79ECECDC5BF8405E880971B2B3B4E0BC.description:
He tells us in Scripture, the living Word of
God (CCC, nos. 80-82).

C1D6D306783A4B0B8D23151FF8A7F131.description:
We also know of his love because he tells us of his
loving plan to save us.

D88F4834F3E644BEA83E3409B873952B.description:
God helps us know and sense his love through
the people and events of our lives (CCC, nos.
897-913, 1069).

7865D1FC601441299534D2BFA8EA6EA7.description:
God continually calls us to union with
him in his Son through the Holy Spirit
by means of a life of holiness (CCC, nos.
1091-1109).

EE815AC8DAB944998A3CF9BFDA9366CF.description:
Jesus lives now and establishes a relationship with each and every one of us,
particularly through the sacramental life
of the Church (CCC, nos. 662-664,
1084-1090).

498BA63EA36B44C486DB5F7048445C9E.description:
God sent his Son to redeem everyone
from sin so that all can share a life of love
eternally with him (Jn 3:16-17; CCC, nos.
599-605).

6F46620BEAFD4662BCCA841986663221.description:
The suffering and Death of Jesus Christ shows
and proves that love (CCC, nos. 599-623).

B327ACED06804495A3EA4AA62760673F.description:
God created human beings in his image
and likeness with the ability to give and
receive love (CCC, nos. 1700-1706).

2496C93828D04B88AE91C9F59817D870.description:
God created the world entirely out of love
and not out of necessity (CCC, no. 295).

7183656705964C5484EBCD0ECD386B96.description:
He shows us his love in creation (CCC, no.
54).

DB4901C4386145DF82C9BC1178D3E8A4.description:
We say God loves us deeply, even in the midst of
suffering, because he reveals his love to us in many
ways, especially in Christ’s taking our suffering
upon himself for our sake (CCC, no. 1505).

CB9E480F75C14A14A665D381D387C156.description:
There are some who see human suffering and conclude
that God does not care about us. Why do we say that he
loves us deeply (CCC, nos. 1503-1505, 1681, 1808)?

612161906C09447EA06774518AD51B59.description:
We can also know God exists through faith. For
those who do believe, through faith as well as
prayer and grace, they can grow in the knowledge
and experience of the reality of God and his
existence (CCC, nos. 143, 153-159).

2806C7713CDD4A009FFCFD0443509506.description:
The faith of people we know today: the pope
and the bishops in union with him; priests
and deacons; parents, grandparents, and other
family members; teachers and catechists;
the witness of fellow Catholics as well as the
witness of non-Catholic believers (CCC, nos.
85, 1655-1658).

B15DA42F3BBC4DEE8055C45CE1215E33.description:
The testimony and witness of others who have
gone before us: people whose stories appear in
the Bible; Apostles, saints, and martyrs (CCC,
nos. 823, 828, 857, 946, 1258, 2473).

E1FD50F3B9574A3A89C71CCBA7D6F319.description:
God’s Revelation comes down to us through
Scripture and Tradition (CCC, nos. 50-53,
74-83).

9C7D893DD0FC4E2C8DD1815C5F06F730.description:
Reason and experience can also teach us to accept
the word of other believers (CCC, no. 39).

A911CD3AE5ED444281EE33067DEF95EE.description:
The natural law written upon each person’s
heart and the longing for God that each person
has also point to God’s existence (CCC, nos.
1954-1960).

043103FF61DA4C8BBA7D8E95BCA9BDD4.description:
Creation did not happen by chance;
throughout history the Church has taught
that someone had to be behind it, and that
someone is God (CCC, nos. 156, 295).

E1FF9558D62F4F5D8ADBB28C8D71E9AA.description:
The order and beauty of the natural world
point to God as the origin and Creator of the
universe (CCC, no. 295).

EF703BCE35D841B7800782D35CD36E83.description:
By looking around at creation, reason and
experience can point to God’s existence (CCC,
nos. 156-159).

A61742334BD1479EB4B66CCDA34FA0DD.description:
Even without the Bible and Divine Revelation,
we can know God really exists through reason
and through experience (CCC, nos. 36-39, 50,
156-159).

E1171C1DE08D4B34B72C0034D31244B2.description: How can we know God really exists?

AFD8457447A84D4FACC244DA4A50CBB9.description:
Jesus also tells us of the goal in this life and of the end
of life.

71D1EB1B6C074F3CAD2E00B0E9B649C1.description:
Jesus sends out his disciples to evangelize (Lk 10:
1-20; Mt 28:16-20; CCC, nos. 861, 905).

6CC1927D17744E19B9D74D7FD3659714.description:
Jesus Christ intercedes for us (Jn 14:13,
16:24; CCC, nos. 2665-2669).

EA8453C7B1A84BD1B82BAC5DE39BB97A.description:
The Lord Jesus teaches us to approach
prayer with humility and a sense of need
(Lk 18:9-14).

BC0229561CF046F3A93AD398F3111154.description: Jesus Christ teaches us through prayer:

8636056FE760438DA943DCE2F66E849A.description:
The Lord Jesus teaches the importance of
perseverance in prayer (Lk 11:5-13, 18:1-
8; CCC, nos. 2729-2737, 2742-2745).

F9327D6BD7F24856A73B5E412E63D3DB.description:
Jesus Christ teaches his Apostles and
disciples to pray (Mt 7:7-11; CCC,
no. 2609).

AF6F000DFD6D4CFE8FB7F175E0268C08.description:
Going off by himself to pray teaches us
the importance of finding time for prayer
(Mk 1:35, 6:46; Lk 5:16).

758D0DD315FC47ECBD7CE60D8310DA58.description:
In the Gospels, the Lord Jesus teaches us
about prayer:

4C44C1479FD049B9B1A7A42D6AD073CE.description:
He teaches us to pray and teaches us through prayer
(CCC, nos. 2607-2615).

64BE7487252A456BB45FF6AF5FE7DAE5.description:
Teaching about the final judgment (Mt 25:
31-46; CCC, nos. 544, 1033, 1373, 2447,
2831).

B7E6B94F07564CF5A47723113A877E93.description:
The Two Great Commandments: love of God
and love of neighbor (CCC, nos. 2083-2557).

D672CF2C810647A2B1C47B56C5B0625F.description:
“Good teacher, what must I do to inherit
eternal life?” (Mk 10:17-22).

76100169833A4EDAB061C959316F0826.description:
Parables and other teaching of Jesus Christ
(CCC, no. 546).

182489D867A140E2815AFB817BF75EA6.description:
Lessons from the Sermon on the Mount
(Mt 5–7; CCC, nos. 1716-1724).

A17460DBDC564A70B5BF1077EA25A602.description:
We are conformed to Christ and can grow in
holiness and goodness.

9BE3B6A1C50049B4960FFB3845E26C98.description:
We become the free adopted children of the Father
through Baptism (Gal 4; CCC, nos. 1265-1270).

2C89AF18C0AD4B50A1473754194533A4.description:
By becoming man, and by his Death and
Resurrection, Jesus Christ unites us to God (CCC,
nos. 461-464).

5E3FAFD36775486A9DB825A1BE9E4686.description:
Jesus Christ reveals the Father to us, who we are, and
our call to holiness.

D57A391B2D954248B5400BD67FF0B9C8.description:
He teaches us how to be single-hearted in our
desire for God, to offset the disordered affections
and divided hearts with which we live (CCC, nos.
1716-1717).

BAF30EA5E4814780B3EB40950B92BE99.description:
He reveals the way to repentance and conversion,
teaching us to leave sin behind and to live a new
life in him; he gives us the spiritual power and
grace to overcome evil; he also teaches us about
God’s forgiveness (CCC, nos. 1847-1848).

82E659CB307046BEA908350FAD66C49B.description:
Jesus invites us to believe in him, to invite him
into our hearts, and to follow him and his teaching
as the path that leads to life, for he is “the way,
the truth, and the life” and is worthy of our belief,
adoration, and love (CCC, nos. 1741-1742).

5B108642072C4417AF9273C63DD8C91D.description:
Jesus Christ redeems us and gives us his grace so that we
can choose the good according to God’s will and resist
sin and its effects (CCC, nos. 1705, 1708-1709).

5A0B1F3AC061429F9B7E0175C451CA40.description:
God has entrusted his creation to us; we are
stewards charged with procreating and protecting
life and using the rest of creation respectfully
(CCC, nos. 287, 354).

B9F7A57FA4DF45D39EBB3EDC43E3970A.description:
The Incarnation affirms that we are created as
good, but in need of salvation, and are meant
for eternal glory with God. The Incarnation
also describes how God continues to work out
our sanctification in the world, e.g., Church,
sacraments, priesthood (CCC, nos. 461-469).

FCB039C16A474A479614C7E13722946E.description:
To be fully human means to fully accept and
become the person God created us to be, a human
person endowed with special gifts which reflect
God: immortality, intellect, free will, the ability to
love (CCC, nos. 356-358, 1702-1706).

77F23262E70D489FB220DCD39CC05044.description:
God created the human person in his image and
likeness; male and female he created them. This
is why we must respect the dignity of all people
(CCC, nos. 1700-1709).

D388012D9F8B46C4B564F16F03AC7721.description:
Jesus embodies what has been revealed in and
through creation.

11485FB648174DC4ABEC14B1C81E6226.description: Jesus Christ Teaches Us About Ourselves

077D0B5184DC4BF787D42F4BA87E2EAC.description:
The unity of the two natures in the one Person is
called the “hypostatic union” (CCC, no. 468).

1BCFB0D4A5F941BCBC9F7D38482DE257.description:
Through things such as hunger and thirst in
the desert, temptation by the Devil, grief at
the death of Lazarus, agony in the Garden of
Gethsemane, and his Death on the Cross, we
know that he also experienced pain, suffering,
and sorrow. In his human encounter with the
sick and the outcast, he personified compassion
(CCC, no. 538).

53930BCD68814BE6BDE7A2ECC500F5F5.description:
In his family life, his friendships, and his
socialization with others we see him experience
human joy and happiness and demonstrate
human virtues.

4267F7BB20754E2DA18CD34E19CC3AAB.description:
Jesus showed his humanity in every event of his
human life (CCC, nos. 512-534):

2BB2DAF8773F4E4FB2D6621ECF01281B.description:
Jesus Christ took on a human nature. The eternal
Son of God incarnate worked with human hands;
he thought with a human mind. He acted with a
human will, and with a human heart he loved. He
was like us in all things except sin (CCC, no. 470).
Man’s creator has become man (CCC, no. 526).

99ECB2F6067541CEB6579C50EA4ED849.description:
Jesus Christ, a Divine Person, is truly the Son of
God, who, without ceasing to be God and Lord,
became man and our brother (CCC, no. 469).

797A785EA25644E1BC43FF7FA2EC047A.description:
Jesus Christ is fully God and fully man (CCC, nos.
464-469).

9DEF35BE5C4642BF9567A48D0F2E0E02.description:
Mary is the Mother of the Church (CCC,
no. 507).

7DD4709EA2D9427E8B0A6077EC438D5B.description:
Explain references in the Gospels to the
brothers and sisters of Jesus (CCC, nos.
500-501).

72293FB0300446CFB79DACD182C0FF49.description:
An unparalleled recipient of God’s grace:
Immaculate Conception; Assumption
(CCC, nos. 490-494, 966).

CF7DB066C67D4F659BFFECCF833FC03E.description: Unique role of Mary, the Mother of God.

FA38B4BC1E234FCD97FABD1762B34952.description:
Church teaching articulated to battle
Gnosticism, Arianism, Nestorianism,
Monophysitism (CCC, nos. 464-469).

B37BD2F149B642D0A6985B3B924A514D.description:
The struggles of the Church to maintain
apostolic faith in light of Christological controversies and heresies (CCC, nos.
249-252).

BA24902D5939457280DCC1356D613598.description:
The development of Trinitarian theology in the
early councils of the Church (CCC, nos. 245-248).

A06302F8D5EE4350B92E44AA5D5B7C2A.description:
Sanctifier of the Church and her members,
e.g., gifts and fruits of the Holy Spirit (CCC,
nos. 32, 731-741, 1830-1832).

23DFDDC252D245018439A7642428365B.description:
Only fully revealed by Jesus (CCC, nos.
689-690, 727-730).

D37487855FF24FD5A30A1CA42CF43151.description:
Eternally proceeding from the Father and the
Son (CCC, no. 687).

7639DB88BB704033B12404B80226F894.description:
The Third Person of the Trinity: the Holy Spirit,
the Lord and giver of life (CCC, nos. 243-248).

13238D75A6E94A7ABB6CC010285F447A.description:
Son of Mary, true man; the perfection of who
we are created to be (CCC, nos. 430, 456-469,
484-487).

CA0F88978BEA4D44B9864399749B6ADC.description:
Son of God, true God, consubstantial with the
Father (CCC, no. 252).

C821E844BEB94A1B80F82C937FD605CD.description:
Jesus Christ is eternally begotten and incarnate
in time (CCC, nos. 461, 422).

5672CA631D534BE9A70F976D6AD6FBC0.description: The Second Person of the Trinity: God the Son.

049B6B48A6054A9EAAF8F767CACF5874.description:
God the Father of mercy also cares for the
unbaptized (CCC, nos. 1257, 1260-1261).

B2B75F61A53246A1A6CCC9AF2A02EA33.description:
God is Father to all those baptized as his
adopted sons and daughters through and in the
Son (CCC, nos. 232-233, 249).

E3CEC08F81C347A4A4AF4C27ABD34D75.description:
God is Father in relation to the Son from all
eternity (CCC, no. 240).

DBB38942B7B44230B6000385EC9CC2B9.description:
God the Father is the source of all that is,
visible and invisible.

C5975463B95249A18444CCB1F9F8691A.description:
The First Person of the Trinity: God the Father
(CCC, nos. 238-242).

67C2F1D14B7D442284DBD0FFC573AF6B.description: The Three Divine Persons of the Trinity.

9F2CA689B042448D9BF6D7BBCA6B42B6.description: God the Father’s love is faithful and eternal.

F5D65CC3B87342D198852AB756ED0049.description:
Jesus teaches us that God is loving, caring,
healing, forgiving, true, just.

357D58F042DB4D40959E9D7BB9F3F882.description:
God is the Father: Jesus Christ’s Father and
our Father.

DE708168507D4D488A54DE01C3BB074E.description:
Each Divine Person shows forth what is proper
to him, especially in the Incarnation and the
gift of the Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 258, 267).

2E4B88C218494188A9D15CCC8B99DF5F.description:
The Divine Persons are relative to one
another; each is God whole and entire; all
three persons share the same attributes, i.e.,
all-loving, eternal, etc. (CCC, nos. 255-256).

279A240C23504B4C8601D50ADD29A13C.description:
The Divine Persons are distinct from one
another (CCC, no. 254).

86A35016811B402C97798455E556B229.description:
This is the central mystery of our faith (CCC,
nos. 235-237).

28D28F53479446F2BA031C0CD7F87BA4.description:
God is Trinity: one in three Divine Persons (CCC,
no. 234).

03D7F95E18A1406E95F1B37EF08E4D48.description: The Revelation of Jesus about God (Jn 14:9).

5652049B285D4985969265DB73FC3877.description:
All events of Christ’s life are worthy of
reflection and imitation (see Gospel accounts).

768E171950974CD3AEB26C89A6FC73F0.description:
Christ continues his presence in the world
through the Church (CCC, nos. 732,
737-739, 747).

DF0E9D11284B4D98A6AE969E426E121B.description:
Jesus Christ is the Logos, the Word of God, the
fulfillment of God’s promise to Adam and Eve
and to the people of ancient Israel (CCC,
nos. 761-762).

CFF34CC06B9C4756A49E3654EB6FF99A.description: Mystery of the Incarnation: Emmanuel (God-iswith-us) (Jn 3:16-17; CCC, no. 484).

D13DC09EEAC749B0B6E41EF7A9ABDDD6.description:
Son of God from all eternity and Son of Mary from the
moment of the Incarnation (CCC, nos. 486, 496, 487,
501, 721-730).

CB5F8CDF7C1741F69CA512F36E005804.description:
The Magisterium guards and hands on the
deposit of faith and is entrusted with the
authentic interpretation of Revelation (CCC,
nos. 880-896).

D47E43D8389E42CBA847ECDA4E58CD47.description:
The Church is a unity of one faith in one Lord
through one Baptism (CCC, nos. 813-16).

24A351DCC1004982A321E3FE7046EAC0.description: Church is the Body of Christ in the world.

E23384819E6A4DFE8C883C644A15847F.description:
The Church was founded by Jesus Christ
(CCC, nos. 811-812).

096E9630CCC54B1F9171F008AE69D611.description:
The fullness of Revelation is reflected in the life
and teaching of the Catholic Church (CCC, nos.
748-870).

372FB3457F314DB390EFD0B5B8DD1E6A.description:
Religion refers to a set of beliefs and practices
followed by those committed to the service and
worship of God.
